title: ACCC slaps NBN with warning over 'serious breach'
text:
“These legal obligations were enacted to ensure that NBN Co does not distort competition in the market for retail NBN services, such as by favouring larger RSPs.”

An NBN Co spokesman said: "NBN Co welcomes the clarity and certainty provided by the undertaking agreed with the ACCC. The undertaking helps give certainty to both NBN Co and the market about the way we build our network and how Australian businesses can benefit.

"Providing competitive offerings to help meet the needs of business has always been part of NBN Co’s intent. The outcomes that we have agreed with the ACCC provide a transparent platform which confirms NBN Co’s crucial role in the business segment. In fact, we’re now even better placed to deliver value for the industry and for business customers."

Until last year NBN Co's focus had been on the residential market, for which it has a wholesale monopoly. But late last year it announced its intention to move more aggressively in the enterprise market, which remains open to competition.

NBN Co insists this was always part of the plan, but the move nevertheless upset the private sector, drawing accusations of "scope creep" and prompting TPG Telecom boss David Teoh to complain to the government that NBN Co was directly targeting TPG's business clients.

At Telstra's full year results in August, chief executive Andy Penn said the move into the enterprise market would cost the telco giant an extra $400 million a year in ongoing annual earnings, bringing the total annual earnings hole to $3.4 billion by 2022.

Last month Mr Penn said he had been "surprised" by NBN's move into the enterprise market.

"I wasn’t necessarily anticipating that, particularly when on the one hand the rollout of the network is slowing down, and on the other hand they’re diverting capital into building more fibre in the CBD than is necessary," he said.

However at the same event Telstra head of enterprise Michael Ebeid said the company would do more deals with NBN Co's enterprise segment as businesses increasingly demand fibre connectivity over copper.

Mr Sims said overall NBN Co's move into the enterprise market was promoting competition.

"Market feedback suggests that NBN Co’s entry into the wholesale enterprise market has increased competition, particularly in areas where Telstra is the only other fixed-line infrastructure provider," he said.
description: The competition regulator has slapped NBN Co with a formal warning for discriminating between retail service providers in the provision of its nascent enterprise business.
